Text: ”His foundation is on the holy mountains.“
Context: This verse expresses joy and esteem for the holy mountains where the Lord’s foundation is set, symbolizing the security and permanence of God‘s dwelling.

Text: ”The LORD loves the gates of Zion more than all the dwellings of Jacob.“
Context: Here, love for Zion is juxtaposed with the Lord’s affection for the other places where Jacob‘s descendants live, highlighting Zion’s special status.

Text: ”Glittering things are spoken about you, O city of God. Selah“
Context: The mention of ”glittering things“ suggests admiration and reverent joy towards the city of God, punctuated by the contemplative pause ”Selah.“

Text: ”I will mention Rahab and Babylon among those who know Me—along with Philistia, Tyre, and Cush—‘This one was born in Zion.’“
Context: This verse lists nations traditionally seen as adversaries, but in an inclusive tonality that anticipates them being acknowledged as associated with Zion.

Text: ”Indeed, it will be said of Zion: ‘This one and that one were born in her, and the Most High Himself will establish her.’“
Context: This expresses pride and a sense of honor concerning those born in Zion, as well as confidence in the divine establishment of the city by the Most High.

Text: ”The LORD will record in the register of the peoples: ‘This one was born in Zion.’ Selah“
Context: The Lord is depicted as keeping a record of those born in Zion, suggesting a divine acknowledgment with a contemplative ”Selah“ to pause and reflect.

Text: ”Singers and pipers will proclaim: ‘All my springs are in you.’“
Context: The joy is high as it envisions a celebration in Zion, with music and songs pointing to the city as the source of life and blessings.
